verses.text: These are the generations of Aaron and Moses at the time when the LORD spoke with Moses on Mount Sinai.
verses.comment: The genealogy signals the priestly lineage that will serve the sanctuary, emphasizing order and ordained roles within God's people. Note the mention of both Aaron and Moses, though only Aaron's sons are listed.

verses.text: These are the names of the sons of Aaron: Nadab the firstborn, and Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
verses.comment: Aaron's sons form the priestly family. Nadab and Abihu are remembered for later failing in their priestly duty (Lev. 10:1-2), showing the seriousness of apostolic succession and proper liturgy.

verses.text: These are the names of the sons of Aaron, the anointed priests, whom he ordained to serve as priests.
verses.comment: Anointing and ordination establish a special priesthood distinct from the rest of Israel (see Ex. 28:41), prefiguring a sacramental priesthood. This hints at apostolic laying on of hands (Acts 6:6).

verses.text: But Nadab and Abihu died before the LORD when they offered unauthorized fire before the LORD in the wilderness of Sinai, and they had no children. So Eleazar and Ithamar served as priests under the supervision of Aaron their father.
verses.comment: This demonstrates the need for reverence in worship and for proper spiritual authority in offerings—an early image of the seriousness of liturgical order (cf. 1 Cor. 11:27-30).

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: A new divine command begins. Each instruction about the Levites comes through revelation to Moses, highlighting the importance of mediation in matters of worship.

verses.text: "Bring the tribe of Levi near, and set them before Aaron the priest, that they may serve him."
verses.comment: Levites are separated for sacred service, becoming helpers to the priests—a type of ecclesial structure that continues later in the Church with distinctions among deacons, presbyters, and bishops.

verses.text: "They shall perform duties for him and for the whole congregation before the tent of meeting, as they minister at the tabernacle."
verses.comment: The Levites act as intermediaries, upholding the holiness of God's dwelling and assisting in worship. Their ministry foreshadows later ministers who serve in the sanctuary for the people.

verses.text: "They shall care for all the furnishings of the tent of meeting, and do the duties for the people of Israel as they minister at the tabernacle."
verses.comment: Levites have a delegated role focused on sacred things, supporting the priests. This division of sacred ministry parallels later forms of ecclesial service.

verses.text: "You shall give the Levites to Aaron and his sons; they are wholly given to him from among the people of Israel."
verses.comment: The Levites are set apart for total dedication, signifying the call of some in the Body of Christ to live completely set apart for God's service (see Num. 8:16).

verses.text: "And you shall appoint Aaron and his sons, and they shall guard their priesthood; but if any outsider comes near, he shall be put to death."
verses.comment: Only those properly authorized may minister at the altar, underscoring God's order and the need for valid ordination—a principle guarding proper sacraments.

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: Here a new instruction begins, reinforcing the authority given through Moses. Revelation continues through chosen intermediaries.

verses.text: "Behold, I have taken the Levites from among the people of Israel instead of every firstborn who opens the womb among the people of Israel. The Levites shall be mine,"
verses.comment: Levites replace the firstborn as God's possession, echoing the Passover context—pointing toward God's sovereign choice and the theme of substitution, fulfilled ultimately in Christ.

verses.text: "for all the firstborn are mine. On the day I struck down all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, I consecrated for myself all the firstborn in Israel, both man and beast. They shall be mine: I am the LORD."
verses.comment: God establishes ownership over the firstborn due to the Passover, a powerful foreshadowing of Christ the Firstborn who is consecrated for all (Col. 1:18).

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses in the wilderness of Sinai, saying,
verses.comment: Another divine instruction is given in the sacred place of Sinai, signifying the holiness attached to both the location and the command received.

verses.text: "List the sons of Levi, by their fathers' houses and by clans; every male from a month old and upward you shall number."
verses.comment: Census from one month old indicates the dedication of even the youngest to the sacred calling, underscoring total commitment to God's service.

verses.text: So Moses listed them according to the word of the LORD, as he was commanded.
verses.comment: Moses’ obedience in detailing the priestly line models submission to God's command, an example for leaders overseeing sacred communities and tradition.

verses.text: Now these were the sons of Levi by name: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
verses.comment: The three Levitical clans show the unified but structured nature of service—different functions, one priestly tribe, reflecting diversity and unity within the faith community.

verses.text: These are the names of the sons of Gershon by their clans: Libni and Shimei.
verses.comment: Genealogical detail provides foundation for hereditary ministry, which becomes important for the later sanctity of priestly succession.

verses.text: The sons of Kohath by their clans: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.
verses.comment: Kohath's descendants are particularly significant, as Aaron and Moses descend from Amram, the eldest son of Kohath.

verses.text: The sons of Merari by their clans: Mahli and Mushi. These are the clans of the Levites, by their fathers' houses.
verses.comment: Merari’s clan holds important tabernacle duties, reflecting the necessity of every branch fulfilling its task in the greater mission of the people.

verses.text: From Gershon come the clan of the Libnites and the clan of the Shimeites; these are the clans of the Gershonites.
verses.comment: Each family’s specific duties and allotment keep order in sacred functions, showing the structure of the priestly ministry.

verses.text: According to the number of all the males from a month old and upward, they were counted: 7,500.
verses.comment: Every detail of the census is important for an ordered priesthood. Nothing is overlooked, echoing Jesus’ teaching about the value of each soul (Luke 12:7).

verses.text: The clans of the Gershonites were to camp behind the tabernacle on the west,
verses.comment: The location of the camp is divinely assigned, signifying the order of God even in the community’s daily life.

verses.text: with Eliasaph the son of Lael as chief of the fathers' house of the Gershonites.
verses.comment: Leaders are chosen for each clan, emphasizing succession and stability.

verses.text: The responsibility of the sons of Gershon in the tent of meeting included the tabernacle, the tent with its covering, the screen for the entrance of the tent of meeting,
verses.comment: Specific duties ensure the proper worship environment and protect the sacred sanctuary, highlighting the importance of care and reverence.

verses.text: and the hangings of the court, the screen for the door of the court that is around the tabernacle and the altar, its cords, and all the work related to them.
verses.comment: Such service protects the holy space. This careful stewardship finds its ultimate fulfillment in guarding God's house in every age.

verses.text: From Kohath come the clan of the Amramites, the clan of the Izharites, the clan of the Hebronites, and the clan of the Uzzielites; these are the clans of the Kohathites.
verses.comment: Kohath's clans are responsible for the most sacred objects. Aaron's household comes from Amram, underlining their central liturgical importance.

verses.text: According to the number of all the males, from a month old and upward, they were 8,600, keeping guard over the sanctuary.
verses.comment: Kohathites’ rather large number indicates the considerable responsibility for the holiest articles of the tabernacle.

verses.text: The clans of the sons of Kohath were to camp on the south side of the tabernacle,
verses.comment: Careful arrangement around the tabernacle balances responsibilities and access among the Levites and Israel.

verses.text: with Elizaphan the son of Uzziel as chief of the fathers' house of the clans of the Kohathites.
verses.comment: Ordered hierarchy among the Levites models proper spiritual leadership and communal obedience.

verses.text: Their responsibility was the ark, the table, the lampstand, the altars, the utensils of the sanctuary with which they minister, the screen, and all its service.
verses.comment: The holiest items accompany the ministry of the Kohathites—prefiguring the entrusted care of sacred mysteries, and the reality of presence in worship.

verses.text: The chief of the chiefs of the Levites was Eleazar, the son of Aaron the priest. He had oversight of those who kept guard over the sanctuary.
verses.comment: Aaron’s firstborn, Eleazar, leads the Levites. Hierarchical authority ensures unity and right worship, analogous to spiritual headship in the faith.

verses.text: From Merari come the clan of the Mahlites and the clan of the Mushites; these are the clans of Merari.
verses.comment: Merari’s lineage assumes practical responsibility, demonstrating how every charism in the people of God contributes to orderly worship.

verses.text: Their number according to all the males, from a month old and upward, was 6,200.
verses.comment: Merari counts as the smallest group, yet with important logistical roles in worship, supporting the whole sanctuary.

verses.text: And the chief of the fathers' house of the clans of Merari was Zuriel the son of Abihail. They were to camp on the north side of the tabernacle.
verses.comment: Even the practical service is dignified with strong leadership; all components are essential in the body.

verses.text: The appointed duty of the sons of Merari included the frames of the tabernacle, its bars, pillars, bases, and all its accessories, all its service,
verses.comment: Every structural detail is attended to, reminiscent of St. Paul's emphasis on the many parts of Christ's one body (1 Cor. 12:12-31).

verses.text: as well as the pillars of the court all around, with their bases, pegs, and cords.
verses.comment: Merari’s sons safeguard even the least visible parts, affirming that all service in the sanctuary matters to God.

verses.text: Those to camp before the tabernacle on the east, before the tent of meeting toward the sunrise, were Moses and Aaron and his sons, keeping guard over the sanctuary for the people of Israel. Any outsider who approached was to be put to death.
verses.comment: Moses and Aaron camp on the east, the place of honor. Protection of the sanctuary is strict, prefiguring the New Covenant reality where sacred mysteries are guarded by proper authority.

verses.text: All those numbered of the Levites, whom Moses and Aaron numbered at the commandment of the LORD, by their clans, all the males from a month old and upward, were 22,000.
verses.comment: The census totals 22,000 Levites, demonstrating the sufficiency and completeness of God's provision for his house.

verses.text: The LORD said to Moses, "Number all the firstborn males of the people of Israel, from a month old and upward, and take the number of their names."
verses.comment: This census of the firstborn echoes Israel's redemption in Egypt. It also illustrates the principle of each soul being precious and consecrated.

verses.text: "And you shall take the Levites for me—I am the LORD—instead of all the firstborn among the people of Israel, and the cattle of the Levites instead of all the firstborn among the livestock of the people of Israel."
verses.comment: Levites and their cattle are substitutes, pointing to later practices of substitutionary sacrifice—all anticipating Christ becoming our Redeemer as the Firstborn.

verses.text: So Moses counted all the firstborn among the people of Israel, as the LORD commanded him.
verses.comment: The census fulfills God's command, given to Moses as the mediator, reminding us of Christ as the one true Mediator (1 Tim. 2:5).

verses.text: And all the firstborn males, by the number of names, from a month old and upward, as listed, were 22,273.
verses.comment: 22,273 firstborn males are counted—slightly more than the Levite males (v. 39), requiring a special provision for the excess.

verses.text: And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: A new command continues God’s care for even the smallest details regarding his people.

verses.text: "Take the Levites instead of all the firstborn among the people of Israel, and the cattle of the Levites instead of their cattle; the Levites shall be mine: I am the LORD."
verses.comment: Repetition emphasizes the unique dedication of the Levites and the principle of substitution—again shadowing Christ’s unique High Priesthood.

verses.text: "And as the redemption price of the 273 of the firstborn of the people of Israel, over and above the number of the Levites,"
verses.comment: Provision is made for the 273 excess firstborn—showing God’s meticulous care and need for specific acts of redemption.

verses.text: "you shall take five shekels per head; you shall take them according to the shekel of the sanctuary (the shekel is twenty gerahs),"
verses.comment: Five shekels per redemption reflects set prices for redeeming the firstborn (Ex. 13:13; 30:13), a provision kept in later ritual.

verses.text: "and give the money, with which the excess number of them is redeemed, to Aaron and his sons."
verses.comment: Redemption money is for Aaron and his sons, supporting the priesthood—a reminder that priestly ministry is sustained through offerings (1 Cor. 9:13-14).

verses.text: So Moses took the redemption money from those who were over and above those redeemed by the Levites.
verses.comment: Faithful obedience to precise ritual regulation is modeled by Moses—an important illustration of the Church’s call to cherish sacred tradition.

verses.text: From the firstborn of the people of Israel he took the money, 1,365 shekels, by the shekel of the sanctuary.
verses.comment: The sum given is exact, confirming that all provision and offering in the sanctuary is accountable to God’s standards.

verses.text: And Moses gave the redemption money to Aaron and his sons, according to the word of the LORD, as the LORD commanded Moses.
verses.comment: Priestly provision is established as a divine ordinance, supporting those who serve at the altar through the people’s gifts. This models the enduring provision for spiritual ministers.
